title: Populous acquires Fentress to expand aviation and public sector capabilities
author: Niall Patrick Walsh
byline: By Niall Patrick Walsh Jun 10, '25 2:00 PM EST
excerpt: Populous has announced the acquisition of Denver-based Fentress in a move intended to expand Populous’ capabilities in aviation and public sector design. Under the acquisition, Fentress will rebrand as Fentress Studios, a Populous Company, retaining its offices in Denver and Washington D.C...
text: Populous has announced the acquisition of Denver-based Fentress in a move intended to expand Populous’ capabilities in aviation and public sector design. Under the acquisition, Fentress will rebrand as Fentress Studios, a Populous Company, retaining its offices in Denver and Washington D.C. Incheon International Airport by Fentress. Image credit: Paul DingmanBoth firms are among the largest firms in the U.S., with Populous becoming the eighth-largest by revenue as per a list released by the Architectural Record last week. Fentress meanwhile sits as the 58th largest by revenue, up from 112th in the previous year. The merger comes weeks after Stantec became the second-largest US architecture firm following its acquisition of Page. Earlier this year, meanwhile, Michael Graves Architecture acquired Kollin Altomare Architects while last year RODE Architects acquired McMahon Architects.
html:
Populous has announced the acquisition of Denver-based Fentress in a move intended to expand Populous’ capabilities in aviation and public sector design. Under the acquisition, Fentress will rebrand as Fentress Studios, a Populous Company, retaining its offices in Denver and Washington D.C.

Both firms are among the largest firms in the U.S., with Populous becoming the eighth-largest by revenue as per a list released by the Architectural Record last week. Fentress meanwhile sits as the 58th largest by revenue, up from 112th in the previous year.

The merger comes weeks after Stantec became the second-largest US architecture firm following its acquisition of Page. Earlier this year, meanwhile, Michael Graves Architecture acquired Kollin Altomare Architects while last year RODE Architects acquired McMahon Architects.
